image.altText: Bondi Junction Stabbing Rampage

props.synopsis: NSW's police commissioner says it's "obvious" from CCTV the Bondi attacker "focused on women and avoided the men" as the prime minister applauds the actions of people who responded. Follow live.

title.children: PM applauds Australians' 'heroism' amid Bondi stabbings, NSW Premier says baby's condition has improved

liveBlogKeyEvents.title: Health minister 'delighted to report' nine month old's condition has improved
$18 million immediately forwarded to coroner's office
Chinese national identified as sixth victim

image.altText: Composite image between Bruce Lehrmann and Lisa Wilkinson.

props.synopsis: A federal court judge delivers a long-awaited decision in the defamation case brought by former Liberal staffer Bruce Lehrmann against Network Ten and journalist Lisa Wilkinson.

title.children: Bruce Lehrmann told 'deliberate lies' in defamation trial and Brittany Higgins was a 'complex … unsatisfactory' witness, judge finds

liveBlogKeyEvents.title: Bruce Lehrmann's account of that night 'an elaborate fancy'
Ten publishing the allegation was not reasonable, Justice Lee finds

image.altText: Photo illustration Channel 10, Lisa Wilkinson, Bruce Lehrmann, Brittany Higgins and Channel 7 on a dark background

props.synopsis: A federal court judge is set to deliver his long-awaited decision in the defamation case brought by former Liberal staffer Bruce Lehrmann against Network Ten and journalist Lisa Wilkinson. Here's what they stand to gain — or lose — from the outcome.

title.children: It's judgment day in the Lehrmann defamation case. Here's what each party stands to win or lose

image.altText: Hay Loading

props.synopsis: Producers in WA's south are facing a grim outlook as dams dry up and feed supplies run short, with some saying they have never seen such extremes before.

title.children: WA government rules out subsidies for farmers facing feed shortage as 'seasons get hotter and drier'

image.altText: Karen Brock from Brocklands nursery and garden supplies

props.synopsis: Suppliers of garden plants to Australia's biggest hardware chain are reporting treatment from the company allegedly so severe that the resulting stress on nursery owners has broken up marriages and left some feeling like "slaves" and "serfs".

title.children: 'I thought it would kill me': Bunnings suppliers break silence about hardware chain's strategy

image.altText: Three children lay flowers at Westfield Bondi Junction

props.synopsis: Bondi Junction Westfield is somewhere people take their kids to the movies on the weekends and teenagers hang out with their friends. Now, people are struggling to process how a mundane trip to the shops has ended in the violent deaths of six people.

title.children: 'Shopping will be a different experience': Sydney reels after attack where everyday life happens

image.altText: A child watches television

props.synopsis: How do you talk to children about the horror of the stabbings when you struggle to process it yourself.

title.children: How to talk to children about the trauma of the Bondi Junction stabbings

image.altText: Joe Biden and others are seated around a large table in a wood-panelled room.

props.synopsis: Details of a phone call between United States President Joe Biden and Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu following the Iranian attack have emerged.

title.children: Details from the phone call between Joe Biden and Benjamin Netanyahu emerge — as it happened

image.altText: Three men stand around a black rocket booster in a sandy environment.

props.synopsis: Iran's deployment of drones and missiles towards Israel represented a big shift in what had been a shadow war fought through Iran's proxies. The big question now is, what will Israel do in response?

title.children: The shift in Iran and Israel's shadow war marks a dangerous moment for the world

image.altText: Forensic police in blue jumpsuits and masks outside a home cordoned off with police tape.

props.synopsis: Two people have been charged with murder after police conducting a welfare check discovered the body of a woman in her 30s at a home near Busselton.

title.children: Pair charged with murder after woman's body found by WA police conducting welfare check

image.altText: Arnold tunnel

props.synopsis: Arnold Dix helped thousands of migrant workers who were forced to endure slave-like conditions in Qatar in the lead-up to the 2022 FIFA World Cup. This is why he has been anonymous for so long.

title.children: Before this Aussie man was saving workers from an underground tomb, he was quietly helping the 'slaves of soccer'

image.altText: A Cocos Malay man wearing a hat looks pensively up, a yacht with yellow sails on tropical blue water in the background.

props.synopsis: While the Cocos (Keeling) Islands are about to mark their 40th anniversary as a territory of Australia, longstanding issues of inequality make the milestone far from celebratory.

title.children: Fake money and land rights: The story of a remote Australian island community's struggle to be heard

image.altText: A man and woman sit in dimly lit room with mugs in front of them, both smiling and looking down.

props.synopsis: Crushes can strike at work, on the bus or between life-long friends. The choice to share your feelings comes with a raft of risks and vulnerabilities.

title.children: 'Now we're married': When Kate shared her secret crush, it had a happy ending. That's not always the case

image.altText: An older couple share a hug in a bush setting.

props.synopsis: When David asked Shirley to marry him, she told him to ask again when he was serious. A few months later, the pair were married on their farm in regional Victoria.

title.children: David got to know Shirley while driving her to chemo sessions. Then they fell in love

image.altText: Indigenous children watch traditional dancing at a Kimberley cultural festival.

props.synopsis: Schools and tertiary study centres must re-educate Australians after "heartbreaking" lack of awareness about plight of First Nations people led to the failed Voice referendum, leading Indigenous women say.

title.children: Truth-telling through factual history, culture and issues taught in schools the way forward, advocates say

image.altText: A close-up shot of a woman's hand holding a mobile phone showing the Hybrid Reserve website.

props.synopsis: Australians are losing millions to international fraud syndicates posting fake ads on social media. One woman who lost more than $100,000 after being "brainwashed" is determined to stop it from happening to others.

title.children: Australians are losing their life savings to a massive fraud syndicate. This 'furious' victim wants to stop others being burned

image.altText: A skeleton of a giant extinct kangaroo placed over a white background. The bones are brown and arranged horizontally.

props.synopsis: Researchers from Flinders University have described three new species of extinct kangaroo, helping to solve a nearly 150-year-long scientific mystery.

title.children: Scientists discover extinct marsupial double the size of the red kangaroo

props.synopsis: As Westfield Bondi Junction remains closed today following the stabbing deaths of six people on Saturday, an investigation into what happened there could take months before police present evidence to the NSW coroner.

title.children: Bondi Junction attacker 'focused on women and avoided the men', police commissioner says

image.altText: Anthony Albanese and Chris Minns carrying flowers surrounded by crowds

props.synopsis: NSW Premier Chris Minns says a similar memorial to the one honouring victims of the Martin Place Lindt Cafe siege would be examined.

title.children: Memorial for Bondi Junction attack victims to be established: Premier

image.altText: A man with short light brown hair wearing a white shirt looking into the distance.

props.synopsis: Former CFS volunteer Gregory John McGannon, who deliberately lit several bushfires in the Adelaide Hills, has been sentenced to more than 10 years in jail, but will be eligible for parole in less than six years.

title.children: Former CFS volunteer jailed for more than a decade for 2021 Adelaide Hills bushfires

image.altText: Close up of "high court' sign at the High Court of Australia in Canberra.

props.synopsis: A High Court ruling late last year has seen political brawling over immigration detention reach levels not seen for the best part of a decade. This week another case makes its way to the court and the consequences could again be major.

title.children: Last time the High Court heard an immigration case it overturned detention laws. Here's what we know about the next one

image.altText: A man looks at stock prices through the window of the ASX in Sydney.

props.synopsis: A fall on Wall Street has sent Australian stocks lower, while the US dollar jumped as investors grappled with rising geopolitical tensions and persistent inflation that could lead to diverging monetary policy between the US and Europe. Follow the latest updates in our live blog.

title.children: ASX falls as Wall Street ends sharply lower on mixed earnings, Bunnings to appear at a Senate inquiry

liveBlogKeyEvents.title: Star Entertainment plunges as it braces for second inquiry into Sydney casino
Gold rises, oil choppy after Iran attacks Israel
A potential solution for young Australians to own properties

image.altText: Portrait of artist Olive Gill-Hille, wearing black, sitting on a bench in her studio facing the camera

props.synopsis: For centuries, predominantly male wood carvers have fashioned the female figure from timber. But WA artist Olive Gill-Hille is reclaiming this gaze.

title.children: 'It's about reclaiming our shapes': How this artist uses salvaged wood to celebrate women's bodies

image.altText: A man with short white hair is alongside a man with a long white beard

props.synopsis: The warnings of potential action from both sides come as the world calls for restraint, with US President Joe Biden reportedly ruling his country out of any Israeli counter-attack against Iran.

title.children: Israeli military approves 'offensive and defensive action' following Iranian aerial attack

image.altText: Bright lights in the night sky

props.synopsis: As flashes of bright light flew through the skies over the ABC's Jerusalem bureau, we wondered what the coming days would hold for the Middle East.

title.children: How Iran's assault unfolded over Jerusalem as the Middle East enters a new phase

image.altText: A police car photgraphed from the back, showing the rear windscreen smashed in

props.synopsis: A 38-year-old man from New South Wales has been charged with inciting a gathering in Hobart's north at the weekend that allegedly resulted in two police officers being assaulted and three police cars being damaged. A youth leadership coach says it shows the negative influence social media can have on young people.

title.children: A 'disturbance' in Hobart's north is part of a wider problem, and has highlighted the negative power of social media

image.altText: A group of rescue workers wearing orange and carrying bags walking in mud

props.synopsis: Mud slides hit remote villages on the Sulawesi island after a week of heavy rain, reducing homes to planks of wood and concrete.

title.children: At least 19 dead, two missing after torrential rain triggers landslide in Indonesia

image.altText: Cameron Smith lets go of his club as he plays a tee shot at the Masters.

props.synopsis: The Masters have once again eluded Australia's Cameron Smith who has recorded yet another top-10 finish as world No.1 Scottie Scheffler has stormed home.

title.children: Smith's Masters heartache continues as Scheffler claims green jacket

image.altText: Bluey wearing headphones, sits on his front door step with her back to the camer.

props.synopsis: The latest episode of Bluey aired on Sunday, April 7, and ended on a cliffhanger. The bigger question for the Bluey generation of child-wranglers — how do we parent without it?

title.children: For five years I've been living my best Bluey life — I'm not ready for it to end

image.altText: A photo of a freeway with moderate traffic.

props.synopsis: Data shows Melbourne residents are buying and driving cars at a higher rate since COVID, even though more people are working from home. Here's why.

title.children: Why Australia's biggest city has a problem with 'forced car ownership'

image.altText: A person holds a mobile phone in their hand with the screen open to a digital licence with driver's photograph.

props.synopsis: Experts question why only one Australian state has implemented internationally recognised "gold standard" security measures for digital licences ahead of Victoria's statewide launch next month.

title.children: Another state is introducing digital driver's licences. We asked IT experts about how safe your information is

image.altText: A TV still of Ben Whishaw, looking into the camera. He's wearing blue scrubs and surgical gloves and is holding forceps.

props.synopsis: Adam Kay, the doctor turned writer-comedian whose diaries about his career in medicine became a global sensation, visits Australia for the first time this month.

title.children: His book has sold 2.5 million copies and his TV show won him a BAFTA. Meet former doctor Adam Kay

props.synopsis: Hailed as an "exquisite piece of history", this 250-year-old silk gown, or mantua, was controversially created by women in a style that caused quite a stir in its day.

title.children: Tasmania's oldest dress is a fashion masterpiece but its style was originally outlawed
